description: From Middle English losen, from Old English losian, from Proto-Germanic *lusōną, *luzōną, from Proto-Germanic *lusą.

verbs.description: lose (third-person singular simple present loses, present participle losing, simple past and past participle lost)

definitionGroups.group: (transitive) To cause (something) to cease to be in one's possession or capability due to unfortunate or unknown circumstances, events or reasons.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To have (an organ) removed from one's body, especially by accident.
examples: Johnny lost a tooth, but kept it for the tooth fairy.
He lost his spleen in a car wreck.
I’ve lost five pounds this week.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To experience the death of (someone to whom one has an attachment, such as a relative or friend).
examples: She lost all her sons in the war.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give or owe (money) after losing a bet.
To be deprived of access to something.
examples: Users who engage in disruptive behavior may lose their accounts.

entries.meaning: To wander from; to miss, so as not to be able to find; to go astray from.
examples: I lost my way in the forest.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To fail to win (a game, competition, trial, etc).
(transitive) To be unable to follow or trace (somebody or something) any longer.
examples: The policeman lost the robber he was chasing.
Mission control lost the satellite as its signal died down.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause (somebody) to be unable to follow or trace one any longer.
examples: We managed to lose our pursuers in the forest.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cease exhibiting; to overcome (a behavior or emotion).
(transitive, informal) To shed, remove, discard, or eliminate.
examples: When we get into the building, please lose the hat.

entries.meaning: Of a clock, to run slower than expected.
examples: My watch loses five minutes a week.
It's already 5:30? My watch must have lost a few minutes.

entries.meaning: (ditransitive) To cause (someone) the loss of something; to deprive of.
examples: O false heart! thou hadst almost betrayed me to eternal flames, and lost me this glory.

entries.meaning: To fail to catch with the mind or senses; to miss.
examples: I lost a part of what he said.

description: From Old French los, loos, from Latin laudēs, plural of laus (“praise”).
